versions.kind: A comment on a submitted paper

versions.description: A proposed notation for improving the transcription and translation of genealogical sources.
versions.title: A Transcription Notation for Genealogy

versions.description: This paper identifies several functional requirements for places within a GEDCOM database.
versions.title: Places
versions.keywords: place, town, city, street, township, county, country

versions.description: This paper identifies a few functional requirements for files attached to an entity within a GEDCOM database.
versions.title: Attachments
versions.keywords: merge, atttachment, file, image, picture, photograph, document, pdf

versions.description: A persona record contains a transcription of information about a single person found in a single item from source material. Persona records are important components in genealogical systems that support recording evidence and research.
versions.title: Persona Records
versions.keywords: Persona, Person Record, Data Model, Research, Evidence, Conclusion, Nominal Record, Two-tier, N-tier

versions.description: There is a need to model, share, and manipulate relationships other than inter-personal lineage-linkage.
versions.title: Beyond Lineage-Linked
versions.keywords: relationships, community trees, place, merging, sharing, manipulation, sorting, searching, aggregating, reporting, analysis

versions.description: FHISO should maintain a lexicon of terms and their several meanings to help mitigate confusions caused by terms with multiple distinct usages. And example lexicon is included
versions.title: Family History Lexicon

versions.description: This paper discusses the requirement for recording searches, whether proposed, successful or unsuccessful, in addition to the results of the search.
versions.title: Functional requirement for recording searches

versions.kind: A comment on a submitted paper
versions.description: This paper proposes a way of unifying the various types of node in the formalism for modelling genealogical research proposed in CFPS 4.
versions.title: A unified formalism for genealogical statements
versions.keywords: data model, architecture, statement, graph, RDF

versions.description: This paper describes requirements for a Source Detail record and a Place record to be added, and stresses issues such as no extensions, registration and compliance testing, and regular updates, as well as the need to keep the standard as simple as possible.
versions.title: Nine Necessities in a GEDCOM Replacement
versions.keywords: sources, conclusions, citations, formatting, places, events, facts, data model, syntax, extensions, registration, testing, updates

versions.kind: A comment on a submitted paper
versions.description: The principle of sensible disbelief provides useful research-modelling and disagreement-moderating properties in CFPS 4 which are absent from CFPS 77.
versions.title: The Principle of Sensible Disbelief

versions.description: A series of methods for sharing information between different researchers, that are investigating overlapping segments of their family trees, and receiving updates.
versions.title: Asynchronous Collaboration: A Proposal
versions.keywords: collaboration, sharing, cloud storage, UUID, media, photographs, documents, sources, geographic, places, events

versions.kind: A comment on a submitted paper
versions.description: The paper identifies an evidence graph as the basis for an explicitly evidence based and culturally agnostic approach to genealogical information systems.
versions.title: Sources, events, personae, individuals and graphs

versions.description: A substantive vision for FHISO, and a proposal that FHISO's first step in fulfillment of this vision be to validate and ratify the GEDCOM X specification set.
versions.title: A substantive vision and proposal to validate and ratify the GEDCOM X specification set

versions.description: This paper extends CFPS 77's statement mechanism with a means of grouping statements into bundles for the purpose of description which it proposes to use to record provenance infomation and other metadata.
versions.title: Recording provenance using statements about statements
versions.keywords: data model, statement, provenance, sources, metadata, inference, hypotheses, RDF

versions.description: A look at how to include all names associated with a person, in different times, cultures, contexts, etc. A single person might have over a dozen name fields associated with them, and this proposal gives a way to organize them and display them properly, considering the many cultural differences in names.
versions.title: Name Templates
versions.keywords: names, given names, surnames, family, religious, internationalization

versions.description: This paper proposes a structured mechanism for recording the ownership of land, and the holders of titles and offices.
versions.title: Proposal to allow recording the holders of offices, titles and land
versions.keywords: titles, office holders, land ownership, hereditaments, regnal numbers

versions.kind: An updated version of a previously submitted paper
versions.description: This paper proposes a structured mechanism for recording the ownership of land, and the holders of titles and offices.
versions.title: Proposal to allow recording the holders of offices, titles and land
versions.keywords: titles, office holders, land ownership, hereditaments, regnal numbers
versions.changes:
Changed the term property to real estate to avoid ambiguity between a property that a real person once owned, and a property as an arbitrary attribute in the data model. Also corrected a missing ‘not’ in §2 ¶1, and corrected the title of
reference [4].

versions.kind: A comment on a submitted paper
versions.description: This paper resolves some type-safety issues raised in CFPS 79 about the statement formalism of CFPS 77, though which apply equally to CFPS 4's node formalism.
versions.title: Type safety in an extensible data model
versions.keywords: data model, statement, node, type safety, extensibility, discovery

versions.description: This document has ideas on standards for genealogy systems, how to build them, and on information held within genealogy systems.
versions.title: Thoughts on Genealogy Standards

versions.description: This paper proposes a light-weight timestamp type for representing the creation and modification times of digital resources.
versions.title: A trivial timestamp type

versions.description: A list of properties that a citation model should strive to achieve. It is unlike that any single model could achieve them all.
versions.title: Desirable Citation Properties

versions.kind: A comment on a submitted paper
versions.description: This paper considers the proposal to ratify GEDCOM X as a FHISO standard, and supports the adoption of GEDCOM X's container file format.
versions.title: Proposal to use GEDCOM X’s container format

versions.description: This paper describes how GEDCOM currently handles sources and citations, and suggests how a new standard could and should handle them.
versions.title: Standardized Sources and Citation Templates
versions.keywords: sources, citations, formatting, GEDCOM, repository, templates, data transfer

versions.description: Proposal to devise an image meta-data standard to handle copyright, attribution, provenance, and the identification of historical subjects, including their position.
versions.title: Proposal for Image Meta-Data Standard

versions.description: This paper presents a case for allowing dates BC to be recorded using the standard Julian and Gregorian calendars, proposes a representation for such dates that is naturally sortable.
versions.title: Proposal to support dates BC as negative years
versions.keywords: dates, calendars, proleptic calendars, epoch, BC
